awd_titl_txt: Radiation Enhancement in High Temperature Industrial Furnaces to Increase Efficiency and Reduce Pollutants
awd_abstract_narration:
1403339
Atreya

The objective of this research is to develop a novel and desirable combustion technology for high temperature furnaces used in the manufacturing of steel, aluminum, glass, and others.  The conventional burning process in furnaces relies on the heat reflection from furnace walls to achieve heating purpose, thus requiring the isolated flames, much like candles, to be at a higher temperature than at the wall.  High temperature flames generate high level of pollutants such as oxides of nitrogen (NOx) that are responsible for ozone depletion and smog.  The proposed work is to have more evenly distributed flames over a larger volume to achieve the same amount of heating.  Because the distributed flame volume can be generated at lower temperatures, the pollutant emission level can be greatly reduced.  A higher energy efficiency and lower emission levels of greenhouse gases are expected.  This project will also provide training in innovative and industrially relevant research to graduate and undergraduate students.  Students will also have industrial site visits and present their research results at technical conferences.

The concept is based on establishing a Radiation from Homogeneous Combustion (RHC) zone through intense mixing, dilution and preheating of initially separated fuel and oxidizer streams.  The proposed work will: (i) Experimentally determine the RHC operating regime; (ii) Quantify the energy efficiency and pollutant reduction benefits of intense radiation; and (iii) Develop a theoretical/computational framework to enable designing and controlling industrial furnaces. Measurements of spectral and total radiation along with NOx, CO2, CO, O2, soot, and total unburned hydrocarbons will be made to quantify the efficiency and pollutant reduction benefits. This experimental and theoretical work will firmly establish the non-dimensional controlling parameters and the operating domain of the RHC furnace.  The proposed RHC furnace technology is expected to have a tremendous impact on energy efficiency and pollutant formation in the manufacturing industries.  It will yield considerable financial benefits for industries and will make them more competitive.  A significant reduction in greenhouse gas emission is also expected.  Moreover, if 100% O2 is used, the furnace efficiency is further increased and carbon sequestration can be easily accomplished.

por.por_cntn:
Activities

The researchers have adopted the following approaches towards achieving the objectives:

  • Analytical: 1-D analysis based on the interface of a structure similar to a counter-flow flame.
  • Numerical: 3-D analysis using commercial CFD packages (FLUENT).
  • Experimental: Performed on a lab-scale combustor/furnace.

In the analytical approach, a model was developed where both steady-state and transient solutions were obtained in the optically thin limit by noting that: (i) nearly isothermal environment is associated with flameless combustion, and (ii) the chemical reaction must be spread out over the largest possible length scale.

In the numerical analysis, a commercially available CFD solver (FLUENT) was used to run RANS based, reduced order chemistry simulations for various input parameters; and later on, simulations with detailed chemistry were run. This was done to gain insights into the flow structure, mixing characteristics, and the thermal field inside the combustor. The effect of the fuel jet momentum has been investigated.

The experiments mainly focused on using blends containing natural gas and small proportions of sooting fuels like ethylene with the conjecture that presence of soot particles in the reaction zone increases radiation heat transfer. A set-up was developed to facilitate the usage of laser extinction techniques for the combustor. This was a particularly challenging task due to the size of the furnace. It was found that the heat flux read by a sensor is composed mainly of wall radiation. A set of mathematical tools and a cooled probe have been developed to read gas radiation exclusively.

The final goal is to assimilate the knowledge gleaned from all three to develop a theory for ultra-low NOx producing industrial furnaces which function on RHC.

Accomplishments

The experimental results show ultra-low NO, CO and THC and also show that UV emission corresponding to OH is considerably reduced in flameless combustion. This is confirmed by Chemkin calculations. Both the experimental and Chemkin results show that increasing the preheat temperature for the same recirculation rate changes flameless to flaming combustion, indicating more complex requirements for flameless combustion. Three important non-dimensional parameters were found: (i) The Boltzmann number; (ii) The Damkohler number and (iii) The dimensionless Arrhenius factor. These, in addition to the equivalence ratio define the parameter space for RFC. It was also found that the Damkohler number must be small for flameless combustion to be possible and that the Boltzmann number expands the flameless combustion domain. Available experimental data agrees with this analysis.

It is also established that the furnace efficiency (defined as the ratio of the chemical heat input to the heat transfer to the heat sink) is enhanced in the RHC mode of operation. Homogeneous combustion was also initiated and sustained at much higher temperatures (~200 oC higher) than previously reported (for non-externally preheated reactants). While the addition of ethylene into the fuel stream helps produce soot which enhances heat radiation, it also causes some degree of flaming tendency. The resultant inhomogeneity causes a small increase in pollutant formation which necessitates further work towards prescribing an optimal set of input characteristics. Soot volume fraction has been measured along the radial direction at various axial locations which corroborate well with the radiative heat flux measured at the same locations.

The furnace studied has a parallel jet configuration and a set of tools are developed to predict the flow underneath the jets. These are found to essentially be independent of the chemistry of the incoming reactants and hence may be applicable to a broad range of reacting/non-reacting confined turbulent jet arrangements. It is also shown that HC can be attained with enriched oxidizer streams for high-temperature industrial applications. Stagnation length is suggested as a length scaling parameter to account for the influence of multiple nozzles. It performs well in describing a variety of cases with the shape of the velocity curve dependent only on inlet momentum ratio. Stagnation length is also seen to be indicative of the macro flow structure and it emerges as a parameter of interest in analyzing NOx emissions. Unlike the behavior of HC with respect to oxidizer-jet momentum, the behavior with respect to fuel-jet momentum is found to be nuanced and not so straightforward. CO and CH4 emissions are found to be dependent on the chemical composition of the incoming reactants and largely independent of the geometry. It is theorized that future research into oxygen enriched HC must be guided by optimizing the furnace geometry and the in-furnace flow as opposed to high preheat of the incoming reactants (which is one of the most well-established ways to attain HC for diluted oxidizer streams). Such work can potentially lead to development of ultra-low NOx systems while suffering no (or minimal) CO and hydrocarbon emissions penalty.

Continuing and ongoing work is focused on the influence of nozzle shape and swirl injection in abating NOx.
